title: Using Physical Senses to Detect Chemical Agents
brief: How to use sight, smell, sound, and physical sensations to detect chemical warfare agents.
steps: Step 1: Smell - detect newly cut grass/hay odor (choking agents) or almond smell (blood agents).
Step 2: Sight - look for colored liquids/solids, mist or fog after explosions, oily patches on surfaces.
Step 3: Sound - listen for muffled shell or bomb detonations indicating chemical weapons.
Step 4: Physical sensation - note nose/eye/skin irritation as urgent warning signal.
Step 5: Taste - detect strange taste in food, water, or cigarettes indicating contamination.
Step 6: Observe others for symptoms: tears, difficulty breathing, choking, coughing, dizziness.
warnings: Most chemical agents are odorless - do not rely on smell alone
Irritation in nose, eyes, or skin requires immediate protective action
Dead animals or people displaying abnormal behavior indicate agent presence
